content.body:
> <@lucacasonato:matrix.org> It looks like api.csswg.org may be having some issues. My CI runs are failing on the fetch spec: https://github.com/whatwg/fetch/runs/5472598698?check_suite_focus=true

https://drafts.csswg.org/ was wedged again for hours yesterday, so I reopened https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/6528#issuecomment-1061553682 â€” which hasnâ€™t been re-closed yet, so I donâ€™t know if that means theyâ€™re expecting it to break again or what. Anyway I guess http://api.csswg.org/ and https://drafts.csswg.org/ are likely using the same backend.
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @lucacasonato:matrix.org
It looks like api.csswg.org may be having some issues. My CI runs are failing on the fetch spec: https://github.com/whatwg/fetch/runs/5472598698?check_suite_focus=true
https://drafts.csswg.org/ was wedged again for hours yesterday, so I reopened https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/6528#issuecomment-1061553682 â€” which hasnâ€™t been re-closed yet, so I donâ€™t know if that means theyâ€™re expecting it to break again or what. Anyway I guess http://api.csswg.org/ and https://drafts.csswg.org/ are likely using the same backend.

> <@lucacasonato:matrix.org> It looks like api.csswg.org may be having some issues. My CI runs are failing on the fetch spec: https://github.com/whatwg/fetch/runs/5472598698?check_suite_focus=true

https://drafts.csswg.org/ was wedged again for hours yesterday, so I reopened https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/6528#issuecomment-1061553682 â€” which hasnâ€™t been re-closed yet, so I donâ€™t know if that means theyâ€™re expecting it to break again or what. Anyway I guess http://api.csswg.org/ and https://drafts.csswg.org/ are likely using the same backend.

In reply to @lucacasonato:matrix.org
It looks like api.csswg.org may be having some issues. My CI runs are failing on the fetch spec: https://github.com/whatwg/fetch/runs/5472598698?check_suite_focus=true
https://drafts.csswg.org/ was wedged again for hours yesterday, so I reopened https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/6528#issuecomment-1061553682 â€” which hasnâ€™t been re-closed yet, so I donâ€™t know if that means theyâ€™re expecting it to break again or what. Anyway I guess http://api.csswg.org/ and https://drafts.csswg.org/ are likely using the same backend.

content.body: Do we anywhere have in any spec a normative definition of the term _â€œsame-siteâ€_?
content.formatted_body: Do we anywhere have in any spec a normative definition of the term â€œsame-siteâ€?

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body: Do we anywhere have in any spec a normative definition of the term _â€œsame-siteâ€_?
Do we anywhere have in any spec a normative definition of the term â€œsame-siteâ€?

content.body: I thought https://w3c.github.io/webappsec-fetch-metadata/#sec-fetch-site-header used to have at least a clear normative definition for  the `same-site` value of the `Sec-Fetch-Site` header â€” and used that when I wrote up https://stackoverflow.com/questions/66115532/what-does-the-sec-fetch-site-header-mean-why-is-the-origin-header-undefined/66228794#66228794 â€” but now even that spec no longer seems to make clear what it means by â€œsame-siteâ€ (at least itâ€™s not clear for developers reading the spec, in contrast to anybody who might be implementing it)
content.formatted_body: I thought https://w3c.github.io/webappsec-fetch-metadata/#sec-fetch-site-header used to have at least a clear normative definition for the same-site value of the Sec-Fetch-Site header â€” and used that when I wrote up https://stackoverflow.com/questions/66115532/what-does-the-sec-fetch-site-header-mean-why-is-the-origin-header-undefined/66228794#66228794 â€” but now even that spec no longer seems to make clear what it means by â€œsame-siteâ€ (at least itâ€™s not clear for developers reading the spec, in contrast to anybody who might be implementing it)

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body: I thought https://w3c.github.io/webappsec-fetch-metadata/#sec-fetch-site-header used to have at least a clear normative definition for  the `same-site` value of the `Sec-Fetch-Site` header â€” and used that when I wrote up https://stackoverflow.com/questions/66115532/what-does-the-sec-fetch-site-header-mean-why-is-the-origin-header-undefined/66228794#66228794 â€” but now even that spec no longer seems to make clear what it means by â€œsame-siteâ€ (at least itâ€™s not clear for developers reading the spec, in contrast to anybody who might be implementing it)

I thought https://w3c.github.io/webappsec-fetch-metadata/#sec-fetch-site-header used to have at least a clear normative definition for the same-site value of the Sec-Fetch-Site header â€” and used that when I wrote up https://stackoverflow.com/questions/66115532/what-does-the-sec-fetch-site-header-mean-why-is-the-origin-header-undefined/66228794#66228794 â€” but now even that spec no longer seems to make clear what it means by â€œsame-siteâ€ (at least itâ€™s not clear for developers reading the spec, in contrast to anybody who might be implementing it)

content.body: I think the concept of â€œregistrable domainâ€ is very clear and intuitive to everybody, so Iâ€™m glad that was coined and we have that defined in (the URL spec) at least â€” itâ€™s been a big improvement over directly mentioning the public-suffix list and the â€œeTLD+1â€ term

content.body:
by the way, Iâ€™m confused a bit by https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/origin.html#sites, where we have the term â€œsiteâ€ defined as this:
> A site is an opaque origin or a scheme-and-host

â€¦while â€œobtain a siteâ€, in the common case, reduces defined as this:
> origin's scheme, origin's host's registrable domain
